column93: Comments/Additional Information
Our Hazardous Waste Day was a joint tri town event with Hanson and Whitman.
Food waste and textile values are based on estimates from the respective haulers.
All hard to handle bulky / commercial items residents have to deliver to the main transfer station in Edgartown 52 weeks per year items are excepted.

We pay $200 a month for a bulky rigid plastic dumpster to be delivered, we fill it at a Saturday event, then JRM hauls is for baling at Greenworks. I could not figure out how to enter this cost in the form, even though it asked for it.Latex paint is never collected. Oil based paint is collected at HHW events.

Items listed as recycled year round are collected at the Ashby Recycle Center & Transfer Station, open every other Saturday, 9:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m. Scrap metal and e-waste are collected, but no tonnage figures are available as it was not hauled in CY16. We are permitted to collect and collect yard waste but have no tonnages. It is composted, spread by the town and taken for use by residents. Mixed paper tonnage includes cardboard and newspaper.

We also service private commercial haulers that provide curbside recycling and trash pickup tolocal residents and non-Athol residents in neighboring communities. The private haulers account for an additional 1548.27 tons of trash collected. This amount is in addition to the tonnage reported in Question 5. The tons reported on Question 5 are the amounts collected in the PAYT bags.

Enforcement of mandatory recycling will begin once we hire staff with grant assistance. Residents are also directed to NEDT in Sutton for hazardous waste and to Leicester Recycling Center for other materials.
Bulky items are paid with purchased stickers issued in $5 increments. Stickers are applied to items based on a fee schedule posted in various locations and the town website.
Costs for Rigid Plastics, wood waste were cost of container ($150). Other materials recycled (in tons): Batteries (1.5), Books (2.6), Tires (0.8), Shredded Paper (3.62), Propane Tanks (0.5).

RE: Mandatory Recycling~ Belchertown's Solid Waste Transfer Station & Recycling Center Rules & Regulations can be found on the town website: www.belchertown.org. under DPW - There is a side link posted perpetually.These rules are municipally enforced by the Board of Selectmen; enforcement pertains to only those transfer station users (approx. 1600 +/- annual users) who opt to purchase an annual sticker, use orange recyclable bags and adhere to the program.Transfer station attendants(2) are not "on the street" issuing violations, but are charged with upholding the Rules & Regs. They do enforce the need for an access permit sticker for entrance, use of bags, and other fees associated within the facility as a means for municipal enforcement. Violation letters are sent out to those offenders.

Apartments/Condos services are all eligible (non-40B) excluding complexes that choose not to be a part of program. Not determined by # units. Drop off for yard waste (5 weeks) is only for Christmas Trees. No other yard waste may be dropped off. We get quantities for white goods and E-waste in # units combined. All tonnages are estimated. Latex paint accepted in regular trash as long as hard. Oil based paint accepted only at HHW event.
Households with senior citizens receive 40 free 30 gallon stickers per year. These are the only residents who receive this PAYT benefit.

Note that we accept recyclables from commercial haulers at our single stream recycling transfer station including tonnage from Falmouth. Our residential recycling center is partially funded by the sticker fee and bulky item fees. It is also funded, as is our curbside collection program, by the ISWM Dept. Enterprise Fund. The ISWM EF derives revenue mainly from the landfill and from the C&D transfer station. More information can be found by visiting the department's website at townofbourne.com. Also, the notes from 2014 provide more detail about all of our operations. Finally, paint is collected only seasonally, Fridays and Saturdays, April - Oct. Note tonnage for the mattresses includes boxsprings and is for the residential stream only. The average of 50 pounds per unit was used to calculate tonnage as recommended by DEP.

We have been collecting E-waste in a 50 yard container. We have been charged by the haul, no tonnage information was supplied to us. We have recently lost our vendor due to the cost of operating on their part. We had two hauls in 2016. I am guesstimating the tonnage based on past figures
The cost for recycling curbside mixed paper and commingled containers (plastic, aluminum & glass) is included in the overall annual trash/recycling contract with municipal hauler JRM.

Our price to dispose of co-mingle increased from $25/ton to $45/ton as of Nov 1st. 2016.Our rebate for mixed paper increased from $10/ton to $25/ton as of Oct. 15th 2016.Our cost to dispose of E-waste increased $225 per pick-up as of Nov. 1st 2016Our carpet and wood waste numbers are included in our total mixed construction/demolition category.Our yard waste total does not reflect what we pay to process (brush grinding/compost screening) which was $14,150.00. or demo debris brought in by Town departments.We encourage residents to bring oil, based paints to HW days, we have paint/swap shed for residents to use. In addition to recycling rechargeable batteries we now recycle alkaline batteries with our metal pile.We also have book and magazine recycling bins located at our Swap Shop for our residents as well.
All residents are instructed to visit the Transfer Station for any questions on disposal or recycling.

Paint and Paint products collected 6 days per week from April 1 thru October 31 each year. Recycle Center is listed as Municipal HHW Collection Facility for Brockton Residents on Energy & Environmental Affairs Website. Styrofoam,Bulky Rigid plastic, plastic bags, mattresses and carpet collected with curbside trash. City collects from 1 - 5 unit residences and mixed-use (business with attached residence) properties. First 32 gallon barrel per unit included in annual trash fee.

The Town of Charlton utilizes a drop-off center partnered with Southbridge Recycling and Disposal Park in Southbridge, MA which is open to Charlton Residents. The number of households that use the drop off are not tracked. The Town does not offer resident trash/recycling program and residents contract with their own hauler of their choice, but they still can use the drop-off center. There is no cost to the Town to use the drop-off center. There is no fee charged for the drop-off (2) bags of waste, unlimited acceptable recyclables, and one bulk item per week. Residents may be charged a reasonable drop-off fee for additional bulk items.

The Town of Chesterfield is currently in the process of rebuilding their website. I was unable to provide a link to the Bulky Fees on this survey. The Town does plan to have it's website completed this spring. The fees should be posted on the website prior to the RDP grant application period. Plans are to include the link on the grant application. Questions? Please contact Kathleen Casey, HRMC Administrator.
All hard to manage material is collected at main Transfer Station in Edgartown, Ma.

Newspaper included in mixed paper tonnage.Bulky rigid plastics included in tonnage for commingled containers.Mattresses accepted and # billed to DEP under recycle grant.Yard waste is estimate amount.Scrap metal/appliances accepted but not weighed.Joined Devens HPCC in July of 2016 - only 6 months of events twice per month.
C&D and bulky are all mixed (reported in two places)bylaws section 31 http://www.ecode360.com/documents/CO3662/CO3662-BY.pdf#search= mandatory recycling, hauler recycling

For #8: Other Recycled Materials:Rigid Plastics tonnage is from year round collection at Transfer Station roll-off as well as 2 recycling weekends.Textiles & metal tonnages are only from 2 recycling weekends - does not include curbside pickups or Transfer Station drop offs. E-waste tonnage is only from 1 recycling weekend in the fall - the spring event tonnages have not been reported to the Town yet - does not include curbside pickups or Transfer Station drop offs.
Other Recycled Materials - Street Sweepings - 1,001.35 Tons Tires - 11.43 Tons Waste Oil - 2,470 Gallons Fluorescent lamps/CFLs - 0.18 Tons
Twice per year the Sustainability Advisory Committee hosts a collection event for textiles, paper for shredding, electronics, styrofoam and scrap metal.
4. One preschool participates in program; the high school does not. 8. Cardboard includes mixed paper 8. Bulky rigid plastics are included in container collection
yearly revenue for all recyclables is $1,500.00

THE RECYCLE CENTER IS OPEN ON SATURDAYS 9-3 WINTER HOURS AND APRIL-NOVEMBER IT IS ALSO OPEN ON THURSDAYS 2:30-4:30. THE ABOVE RECYCLABLE MATERIALS CAN BE RECYCLED WHENEVER THE CENTER IS OPEN 1 OR 2'CE A WEEK. THE FLUORESCENT BULBS AND HOUSEHOLD BATTERIES MAY BE DROPPED OFF AT THE TOWN HALL WHEN OPEN.
Edgartown local Drop-Off is mixed tonnages for hard to manage materials with the Main Transfer Station one of the same buildings
Oil-based paints are collected twice per year.
styrofoam - 4,450 pounds per yearthe construction debris is tubs, toilets and sinks for recycle at the recycling center wm classifies as construction debris

Generally, to dump at our transfer station one must: (1) be a resident or business in Granville if they show proof of residency; and (2) purchase a punch card with a check. Punch cards cost $75.00 and can be purchased in four bag size preferences: Sixty 13-gallon punches; Thirty 30-gallon punches; twenty 42-gallon punches and fifteen 50-gallon punches. We do not sell or provide stickers. The PAYT program collects enough money to cover our costs, but we appropriate in our budget the amount we believe we will collect in PAYT payments instead of setting up a revolving fund. Our transfer station attendant monitors and enforces the mandatory recycling requirement at the transfer station. Local private haulers are responsible for enforcing the mandatory recycling for their customers. In lieu of residents having access to a comprehensive household hazardous waste collection event in another community, the town does contract with NEDT Household Hazardous Products Collection Center in neighboring Westfield to provide year-round opportunity to dispose of a comprehensive list of hazardous products not accepted at the Transfer Station. To incentivize the program the Town pays the first $30 of residents' costs for disposal. This program is advertised at the Transfer Station, on the Town websites and several times a year in the local monthly newsletter. Nearly one ton (0.82) of hazardous materials were collected in CY 2016 at NEDT from Granville residents.
We accept HHW year round from Greenfield and Leyden Residents
Bulky and C&D are collected in the same container and sorted by the hauler. A total 586.56 tons were collected. Approximately half is bulky and half C&D collected.
Bulky waste and C&D are collected together and recycled at the collection facility, Devens Recycling.

-Condo complexes and apartments up to eight (8) units are collected through the City's program. 9+ units must be private collection. -Bulk Items - Limit one (1) per residential customer per week free of charge. Any additional items must be paid per fee schedule. -Bulk Item tonnage only includes 9 months of program since inception of Automation. (YTD = 242 tons. Anticipated full year = 360 tons)-Trash Limit - One (1) sixty-four (64) gallon cart for trash issued to each eligible household. All trash must fit inside the cart unless resident chooses to utilize Overflow Bag Program or renting an additional cart from the City. -Tires - Collected 509 Individual Car Tires. 2 Truck Tires and 3 Loader Tires.

Ipswich pays $350 per MONTH, not by cubic yard or ton, to dispose of our yard waste from our dropoff facility. Ipswich has an opt-in, private-pay curbside composting program. Residents pay $1 per week and the DPW pays 10 cents per household per week. The approximate total cost for 2016 (with fluctuating rates of participation by season) to the DPW was $2,545. This is a reduction from prior years because our new contract does not charge a tipping fee. Our trash and recycling household numbers are different because we collect recycling from some residences and businesses that we do not serve with trash hauling. We have a very dense downtown and our hauler picks up recycling from there as well. We also offer recycling dropoff at our transfer station. In addition, we serve curbside trash and recycling pickup to multi-family residences (four units or more) that were "grandfathered in" before the new trash policy was adopted. The textile tonnage is an estimate from our schools' bins based on reports from the schools. They receive $100 per ton. In addition, we have an American Red Cross box at our transfer station that collected approximately 1.5 tons, but it is not included in the total because we receive no payment and there isn't an option above to separate the two. E-waste is estimated using EPA.gov conversion amounts, because we are charged for e-waste per unit, not by weight. In the past, we included our e-waste with the Recycling Committee's 3 town events, but now we have our own recycling pickups. Ipswich has two dumpsters for scrap metal, one at the transfer station for residents and the other at the DPW yard for municipal buildings and schools. Our bulky items include furniture, mattresses and box springs, and carpet. Appliances can be brought to the transfer station for free or picked up curbside by pre-paying for pickup with the hauler (not the town). As mentioned above, e-waste is separate from bulky items.
Seniors pay $90/year for transfer station permit.Bulky waste and C&D are mixed together, listed twice.BOH passed hauler regulation in November, effective April 2017.

Note: AS we have done in the past, we continue to collect textiles and used clothing in numerous containers at the transfer station. These materials are donated to Red Cross, etc. The clean wood program is in place and has been successful in diverting clean wood out of our bulky containers. We also see a 50% disposal savings with the clean wood. The mattress program is in place and has also been very successful. We take the mattresses to Ace Mattress in Rhode Island for recycling. This has also been another cost savings program for the town. I have not yet implemented a swap shop, which the town just recently was awarded SMRP grant funds for.
Thank You ALL so much!
residents pay for disposal of items at the AKS recycling center.
Leyden residents can access Greenfield's transfer station for paint, oil, antifreeze, lamps, etc. and Greenfield's permanent hazwaste program at the Greenfield wastewater treatment plant.

Again, we are break even with our recycle. We pay for the haul, but receive no revenue nor pay for the disposal.We do receive a check for scrap metal and we pay for electronics and white goods. Unfortunately these have not been recorded in a fashion that is easy to retrieve.I will be changing the record keeping for 2017.

For Q. 5b) re: Bulky Waste tonnage.WM collects bulky items curbside.In CY16 they collected 3,482 items (couches, tables etc)However I do not have a weight...BTW From 8. (other-Textiles) 131,430 Lbs from Bay State Textiles {14 bins} PLUS 230,407 Lbs from PlanetAid {14 bins} = 361,837 => 180 TONS!!Thanks!

The Town of Lunenburg is a member of Devens Regional HHW Collection Center which collects many of the other recycled material not collected at the curb. The town is next to the Town of Townsend and has access to their drop off recycling center which is open twicea month. The town is also a member of Nashoba Boards of Health which collects sharps year round.

The number of households served differs from last year's due to changes in apartments and senior housing. Lynnfield, through our hauler, collects appliances, grills, humidifiers, lawnmowers, and other items via pre-paying for pickup to the hauler. Because we receive tallies from the hauler in units and not weight, it is difficult to estimate diverted weight. Lynnfield hosts Planet Aid boxes at town hall for textiles, but numbers were not available at reporting time. Lynnfield's hauling contract expired in June, and the $25 per ton rebate for recycling paper was replaced with a $25 per ton cost for all recyclables. Because there is not a method for splitting the calendar year (hauling contract runs by fiscal year), it seemed best to use the new recycling costs because those are the numbers going forward through 2021. Actual paper and comingled recyclables costs reported here are approximately half for calendar year 2016. E-waste is similar to appliances, because TVs and monitor pickups are prepaid to the hauler and reported in units. Weight estimates were made using the EPA conversion amounts.

Hazardous Products Collection sponsored by CMW District. Scrap Metal/White Goods, C&D Materials, Swap Shop or Book Re-Use by CMW District #8 (other recycled material) scrap metal/white goods and e-waste - CMW District. Medical Waste/Sharps-Board of Health. Recycling Tonnage - cardboard, steel/tin cans, glass, plastic, newspaper - included in single stream. Bulky waste is accepted at the CMWRRDD Transfer Station. They would be responsible for tracking the tonnage collected.
We have hosted a joint Hazardous Waste Collection Event with the Town of Hudson for the past several years.

Collection frequency of other recycled materials. I checked off 3 - 10 weeks for drop off of waste oil and filter,oil based paint, thermostats, we collect it 6 months of the year from May -October.Yard Waste is collected curbside and can be dropped off. The town mulches it and turns it into compost for the Residents. I don't have a dollar amount for cost. The town does it themselves.
The city of Medford 6 events - collection of latex and oil base paint from Medford residents ONLY.
ewaste collection was seasonal, Saturdays, 4/9-11-26
Mattresses/Boxspring, Computer and Electronics, Carpet, Upholstered Furniture, and White Goods - $15.00 each - town charges $21.00.

Date Town and Location Hours NotesApril 30 Winchester 15 Lake St 9-1 Checks only, payable to CVCCApril 30 Natick 75 West St 9-12 Call to register, (508) 647-6460Checks only, payable to Clean HarborsMay 21 Tyngsborough87 Kendall Road 9-1 Checks only, payable to StericycleJune 18 Wayland 66 River Road 9-12 Checks only, payable to Clean Harbors, Pre-register at http://www.wayland.ma.us/Pages/WaylandMA_Health/HHWDJune 25 Maynard38 Winter Street 8-12 Checks only, payable to Clean HarborsSeptember 24 Sudbury, Curtis Middle School22 Pratts Mill Rd 9-1 Checks only, payable to Clean HarborsOctober 15 Needham470 Dedham Ave 8-12 Checks only, payable to Clean Harbors

The single stream automated cart program began on June 23, 2014.Single unit buildings received 65-gallon carts, multiple unit buildings received 95-gallon carts. Residents who requested smaller carts received 35-gallon carts.Other materials recycled:antifreeze: 0.44 tons batteries: 1.68 tons books: 10.34 tons bulky waste: 1,021.76 tons (general bulky items recycled through New Bedford Waste Services)bulky waste: 261.81 tons (material collected by the "white goods" truck including computer monitors, televisions, laptops, radios, refrigerators, dishwashers, dryers, and scrap metal; there may be some double counting of the scrap metal weights)cooking oil: 1.45 tons motor oil: 2.44 tons oil filters: 0.90 tons sharps: 0.27 tons (Weights from two drop-off events. There are also three locations in New Bedford that accept sharps year-round.)shredded paper: 8.88 tonsStyrofoam: 0.67 tons tires: 6.83 tonsPaint reuse encouraged (local theater accepts latex paint and an artist accepts oil-based paints).

We have a latex paint exchange open 5 days/week May - October. Oil based paint is only accepted through HHW events. We also collect C&D from City operations, but I wasn't able to get a total tonnage in time for submission.

All 8 of the Solid Waste Department's staff are charged with and assist with daily enforcement of the mandatory recycling regulations. No one person is designated but one or more is tasked on a daily basis to check bins, write letters, make or answer phone calls from residents and/or commercial owners regarding their recycling services. In addition the Board of Health's Director and clerical staff also assist in reviewing applications for permits for trash and recycling services and enforce the "integrated services for an integrated price" per the BOH's Hauler Regulations.

Please note: 1) Yard waste statistics for CY2015 were not available at report time last year, so I repeated the CY 2014 figure (482 tons). The correct yard waste tonnage for CY 2015 is 256 tons. The loss is due to closure of the municipal landfill. 2) In 2016 our ReCenter Swap Shop recorded all outgoing material by weight. During the 20 half Saturdays the swap shop was open between 4/9/16 and 10/30/16, we diverted 14 tons of material from the landfill. Of that, 13.8 tons was "adopted" by swap shop visitors and reuse partners (e.g. Salvation Army and Eco Building Bargains). "Unadoptable" material totaled a mere 1.4 tons (.8 ton was recycled and .6 ton was sent to the landfill). Through careful vetting of incoming material we were able to keep the landfilled amount to 4% of the total!

I may have a discrepancy in my yard waste cost and volumes but will need more time to evaluate this. I would also like to discuss the number of households served as I have a PYT program and a private hauler which has 1006 customers and I have deducted that number of households from my total number of households in Town which is 5888 which leaves me 4882. The reason I would like to discuss this is the Town's collection contractor goes by each of the households in Town and the private hauler customers can use both services. Having ore than 5000 households being served would double the value of the points awarded in RDP funds.

Northbridge does not have a municipal trash collection program - the data in this report reflects to the best of our knowledge the activities of the Recycling Center which is run as a drop-off collection site for Northbridge residents.
for question #8, we do not receive a breakdown of trash vs. recycle tonnages. It is cumulative on the billing statement.

Yard waste listed in #8 is Christmas trees collected from Town residents, and sent to a landscape company for disposal. Leaves and grass clippings are collected at the Town's Transfer Station, and all processing is done by the Town at no cost.
The Town of Rockport has an optional PAYT Program.

1-Condos and Apts. section is confusing-we pick up for many large condo complexes where they are seperate units; we pick up for some apartments over 6 units however limit them to 6 sets of toters2-Salem has a trash fee for non-owner occupied and about 216 commercial accounts downtown, this generates about $750,000 annually to offset our trash and recycling costs. Residential fee is $216 annually per unit, as noted. Commercial fee is $318 per unit annually.

If a household already has a Transfer Station sticker they are allowed one Bulky Waste coupon free of charge. If a household does not have a Transfer Station Sticker they are charged $25.00 for a Bulky Waste coupon.

Latex and oil-based paint should not be combined for our purposes; we accept latex paint (solidified to a non-liquid state) year round, while oil-based paint is accepted only in our HHW program.In January 2016, one load of 28 mattresses was sent to our previous vendor, Conigliaro Industries at a cost of $8.50 per unit, total $238, which cost was recovered in fees charged to drop-off customers. Following award of DEP Mattress grant, 184 additional mattresses were collected under the grant program.In 2016, Sherborn began separately collecting porcelain fixtures to send to Conigliaro Industries for pulverization into recycling into aggregate for construction purposes at a cost of $15 per unit plus $90 labor per load. Hardware and other non-porcelain material must be removed to avoid a $5 per unit extra charge. Drop-off customers are now charged $15 per unit. There appeared to be no appropriate place on the survey to report this effort, and although it seems worthwhile to reduce this trash tonnage, even at the risk of incurring some added cost (it is cheaper to ship/tip as trash). We shipped around 80 discarded toilet/sink units during the year, and inventory was building at year's end.
This form was completed by Daniel Morgado not by Kristen Las who is on leave at the moment.
Please note that Shutesbury now has an arrangement with the Town of Leverett that allows Shutesbury residents to utilize the swap and take-it-or-leave it features of the Leverett Transfer Station.
We receive payment for our scrap metal but not for our appliances. Our revenue for scrap metal was $9,153 for CY 2016.

properly dried latex paint accepted all year for disposal. Liquid latex not accepted at any time. Oil based paint accepted at Household Hazardous Waste Day (HHWD). We had a joint HHWD with Easthampton October 29th.

Revenue per ton for scrap metal is based on average pricing during 2016. Southwick partnered with NEDT of Westfield to host year-long HHW collection for Southwick residents. The facility is open 3 days per week (156 days per year). The Town pays for the first $20 of HHW per residence. A link with info for this program is as follows: http://www.southwickma.org/Public_Documents/SouthwickMA_DPW/hazardous_waste.
Co-hosted HHW day w/ North Brookfield at their facility. We provide labor and fees.
For trash and recycle households serves, some condos and apartments in the 5-6 unit range, 7-8 unit range, and 9 and above range are collected as part of the municipal program, but not all.

It is very difficult to calculate the "other recyclable items". they are collected at our hazardous waste day and on a weekly basis. The amounts above are estimates, we do not keep track of the tonnage on these items.Also - the revenue/cost for recycling is in our contract with EL Harvey. It is not broken down. I was not allowed to submit this without putting a number in, so therefore I put in a 0.

Appliances - tonnage not computed separately from trash, but the numbers of appliances are tracked.Compost Bins - Lexington sells compost bins on state contract price to Waltham residents.Rigid Plastics - Currently collect about 10 rigid plastic products; tonnage not computed separately.Tires - City collects and disposes of abandoned tires only.Yard Waste- Have been advised to submit CY only, due to two cost structures (curbside and vacuuming).

Regarding Other Recycled Materials Category: Textiles/Used clothing are collected at Schools in addition to Transfer Station. TS total is 6950lbs, town-wide total is 41,915lbs. Yard waste is collected and ground for mulch, which is used throughout Town by the DPW and available for residents to take. Electronics and E-Waste are collected once a month for recycling and tracked per-item (353 items in CY2016).

Question 4, Commercial Businesses pay a per ton fee for disposal of yard waste, trash, appliances, ties, tvs, fluorescent bulbs, and propane tanks.Question 8, comingled containters are collected separately and sold as individual commoditiesWe also accepted 11 tons of tires
The Wendell Transfer Station accepts scrap metal but the vendor does not pay the town revenue and therefore does not weigh the loads so metal tonnage is not reportable.

Bulky plastic items were collected at our 2016 earth day fair event. Leaf and Yard waste tonnage listed above only includes quantity dropped of by Town Trucks. It does NOT include quantity dropped off by residents or picked up curbside by our hauler.
All hard to manage items are directed to use the main District Transfer station in Edgartown, Ma.

yard waste (brush, not leaves) is accepted at a drop​ off facility on 2 collection dates during 2016. The Fire Dept picks up Christmas trees one weekend after Christmas. Residents pay a fee. This is coordinated completely by the Fire Dept. Bulky waste is collected weekly with normal trash pickup.

tin/aluminum 29.59 tons at $93.00 tons; plastic containers 24.74 tons at $0; Glass 92.82 tons at -$35/ton. HHW Collection in another community is a business "NEDT" located in Sutton, MA (NEDT.org). They are open year round 2 days a week and by appointment and some Saturdays in the summer for Massachusetts, RI & CT residents. Our metal glass and plastic are collected separately. We are currently recycling plastic at a $0 return. The glass is a cost of $35 per ton. The only brush we collect is the Christmas trees during the month of January. We do textile recycling through Bay State and Salvation Army. We only receive the tonnage from Bay State. The mattress shown above are those that do not fit the criteria of our Mattress Recycling Program and are disposed as trash.
HHW reciprocal events twice a year at Abington, Cohasset, Hanover, Hingham, Kingston, Norwell, Rockland, Whitman, Plymouth, Duxbury, Hanson, Middleborough

Item #2 - Curbside Recycling is a available to residents in household units of 6 or less. Drop-Off recycling is available to all household units.Item 6 - Yard Waste curbside is only during Fall Leaf Collection and April through November/December we operate three drop-off sites.#8 The conversion factor for cu. yds. of yard waste appears to be much lower than what has been used in the past and even in the DEP's own Volume to Weight Conversions for Recyclable Material.
